case_vignette: A 19-year-old female college student comes to the physician for a sudden loss of visual acuity of her right eye! She noticed that she was unable to read the time on the alarm clock when she woke up in the morning! When she closes her right eye, she is able to see sharply! When she closes her left eye, she has blurry double vision! She does not recall trauma to her eye but has been working long nights on her honors thesis! She has a history of occasional shoulder luxation! She is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall, and weighs 62 kg (136 lbs); her BMI is 19!1 kg/m2! Her vital signs are within normal limits! On physical examination, slender and long fingers are noted! She has several flat, demarcated brownish nevi on her left cheek! Ocular examination shows upward temporal subluxation of her right lens!
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing sudden loss of visual clarity in my right eye, and when I close that eye, everything appears sharp, but when I close my left eye, I see things blurry and doubled.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I noticed it when I woke up this morning.
Do you have a history of diabetes, hypertension, or any other chronic diseases?
No, I do not have diabetes, hypertension, or any other chronic diseases.
Have you noticed any pain, redness, or discharge from the affected eye?
No, I haven't noticed any pain, redness, or discharge from the affected eye.
Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to the eye or head?
No, I do not recall any trauma to my eye.
Do you have a history of migraines or any neurological conditions?
No, I do not have a history of migraines or any neurological conditions.
Have you noticed any other symptoms like flashes of light, floaters, or a curtain-like shadow over your field of vision?
No, I have not noticed flashes of light, floaters, or a curtain-like shadow over my field of vision.
Have any of your family members experienced similar eye issues, or do they have a history of eye diseases?
I'm not aware of any similar eye issues or history of eye diseases in my family.
Final Diagnosis: Optic neuritis.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports experiencing a sudden loss of visual clarity in their right eye. They describe that when closing their left eye, things appear sharp, but when the right eye is used, they see things blurry and doubled. The issue was first noticed upon waking up in the morning. The patient confirms they do not have diabetes, hypertension, or any other chronic diseases. Additionally, they have not noticed any pain, redness, or discharge from the affected eye. There is no history of trauma to the eye or any past experiences with migraines or neurological conditions. No occurrences of flashes of light, floaters, or a curtain-like shadow over their field of vision have been observed. The patient is also not aware of any similar eye issues or history of eye diseases in their family.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Sudden onset of blurred and double vision in one eye without other symptoms could indicate a refractive error or a possible early sign of a cataract. It is recommended to see an eye specialist for a comprehensive examination to determine the exact cause.

trial_1.summarized_frq: Sudden onset of painless monocular vision loss and diplopia suggests a possible diagnosis of a cranial nerve palsy, most likely involving the third, fourth, or sixth cranial nerve.
